app_metadata.name: Case Interview Framework Navigator
app_metadata.description: Interactive tool to explore case types and frameworks by industry

profitability.name: Profitability
profitability.description: Diagnose why profits are declining and recommend improvements
profitability.when_used: When a company's profits are falling, margins are compressed, or costs are rising faster than revenue

steps: Clarify objective (total profit vs margin, time horizon, scope)
Decompose: Profit = Revenue - Costs
Revenue breakdown: Price × Volume by segment/product/channel
Cost breakdown: Variable (scale with volume) vs Fixed costs
Root cause analysis: market trends, competition, internal efficiency
Generate solutions across revenue and cost levers
Prioritize by impact, feasibility, and timeline

clarifying_questions: Is revenue flat, declining, or growing?
Which product lines or segments are affected?
Have there been recent operational or strategic changes?
What is the competitive landscape?
common_pitfalls: Jumping to solutions before diagnosing the problem
Not separating fixed vs variable costs
profitability.example_prompt: Our client is a 90-year-old beer company. Market declining 2%/year, but their profits dropped 15% last year despite selling 10M bottles. How do we grow the brand without lowering profits?

market_sizing.name: Market Sizing
market_sizing.description: Estimate the size of a market in revenue or units
market_sizing.when_used: To evaluate market opportunity for new products, market entry, or investment decisions

steps: Clarify: what to measure (revenue/units/customers), geography, time period
Choose approach: Top-down (population) or Bottom-up (segmentation)
Break into logical components with clear math structure
Make reasonable assumptions and state them explicitly
Calculate step-by-step, keeping numbers round
Sanity check: does the result make intuitive sense?

clarifying_questions: What geography should we focus on?
Are we measuring total addressable market or served market?
What's the time period (annual, quarterly)?
Should we include adjacent/substitute products?
common_pitfalls: Forgetting to sanity-check the final number
market_sizing.example_prompt: Estimate the annual revenue of the coffee shop market in Austin, Texas.

market_entry.name: Market Entry
market_entry.description: Should a company enter a new market or geography?
market_entry.when_used: When a company considers expanding into new geographies, customer segments, or adjacent markets

steps: Market attractiveness: size, growth rate, profitability, competitive intensity
Company fit: capabilities, brand strength, resources, strategic alignment
Entry barriers: regulations, capital requirements, distribution channels, local relationships
Entry mode: organic build, acquisition, partnership, joint venture
Financial analysis: investment required vs expected returns (NPV, payback)
Risk assessment: regulatory, competitive response, execution, cultural
Recommendation with clear go/no-go decision

clarifying_questions: What is our objective (revenue target, strategic footprint)?
Do we have any existing presence or partnerships?
What are the major regulatory hurdles?
What's our time horizon for profitability?
common_pitfalls: Only focusing on market size without competition analysis
market_entry.example_prompt: A US-based fitness chain wants to enter the Southeast Asian market. Should they proceed, and if so, how?

new_product.name: New Product Launch
new_product.description: Should a company launch a new product or service?
new_product.when_used: When considering developing and launching new products or services

steps: Customer demand: unmet needs, target segments, willingness to pay, market size
Competitive landscape: existing solutions, substitutes, differentiation opportunity
Company capabilities: technology/IP, production, distribution, brand fit
Economics: development costs, unit economics, pricing strategy, volume projections
Go-to-market: channels, marketing, sales strategy, timing
Risks: cannibalization, competitive response, execution challenges
Financial recommendation: expected profit/ROI, break-even timeline

clarifying_questions: What customer problem does this solve?
How is it differentiated from existing solutions?
Do we have the capabilities to deliver it?
Will it cannibalize our existing products?
new_product.example_prompt: A premium coffee chain is considering launching a line of ready-to-drink bottled coffee for grocery stores. Should they do it?

ma.name: M&A (Mergers & Acquisitions)
ma.description: Should a company acquire or merge with another company?
ma.when_used: When evaluating acquisition targets or merger opportunities

steps: Strategic rationale: why acquire (capabilities, market share, vertical integration, technology)
Market analysis: target's industry attractiveness, growth trajectory, competitive position
Target assessment: financial health, assets, management quality, culture
Synergies quantification: cost synergies (eliminate redundancies, scale) and revenue synergies (cross-sell, market access)
Valuation: DCF, comparable companies, precedent transactions; walk-away price
Integration risks: cultural fit, customer/talent retention, execution complexity
Recommendation: acquire/pass, price range, deal structure

clarifying_questions: Why acquire vs build capabilities internally?
What specific synergies can we capture?
What is the target company worth?
What are the integration challenges?
common_pitfalls: Ignoring cultural fit and integration complexity
ma.example_prompt: A regional bank is considering acquiring a fintech startup with a mobile banking platform. Should they proceed?

pricing.name: Pricing Strategy
pricing.description: How should a company price its product or service?
pricing.when_used: When launching new products, repositioning existing ones, or responding to competitive pressure

steps: Cost floor: variable cost per unit (minimum price to avoid losses)
Customer value: willingness to pay, perceived value, price sensitivity by segment
Competition: competitive pricing, market positioning (premium/mid/value)
Business objectives: maximize volume, margin, or market share
Pricing architecture: flat, tiered, subscription, usage-based, freemium, dynamic
Test and validate: surveys, conjoint analysis, A/B tests, pilot programs
Recommendation with expected volume and profit impact

clarifying_questions: What is our cost structure per unit?
How price-sensitive are customers?
What do competitors charge?
Are we a premium or value brand?
common_pitfalls: Pricing below variable cost without strategic reason
pricing.example_prompt: A SaaS company currently charges a flat $50/month. They want to optimize pricing. What should they do?

growth.name: Revenue Growth
growth.description: How can a company increase revenue?
growth.when_used: When a profitable company wants to accelerate top-line growth

steps: Current state: revenue breakdown by product, segment, channel, geography
Growth levers: increase prices, sell more to existing customers (frequency/basket), acquire new customers, new products, new markets
Market opportunity: current penetration rates, addressable market, adjacent segments
Competitive positioning: share gains, differentiation, marketing effectiveness
Profit impact: ensure growth is profitable (check unit economics, CAC/LTV)
Prioritize initiatives: quick wins vs long-term bets, expected ROI
Implementation roadmap with milestones

clarifying_questions: Where does revenue come from today?
What is our market share by segment?
Which customer segments have highest growth potential?
Are there constraints (capital, capacity, brand)?
common_pitfalls: Pursuing revenue at expense of profitability
growth.example_prompt: A regional grocery chain has flat revenue for 3 years. How can they grow top line by 15% in the next 2 years?

cost_reduction.name: Cost Reduction
cost_reduction.description: How can a company reduce costs sustainably?
cost_reduction.when_used: When margins are compressed, facing competitive pressure, or preparing for downturn

steps: Cost breakdown: by category (COGS, labor, SG&A, overhead, capex)
Benchmarking: compare to competitors and industry standards
Opportunity identification: high-cost areas, inefficiencies, redundancies, low-value activities
Generate ideas: process improvements, sourcing/procurement, automation, outsourcing, footprint optimization, scope reduction
Impact analysis: savings vs impact on quality, service, employee morale
Quick wins vs transformational: 30/60/90-day roadmap
Implementation risks and change management

clarifying_questions: Which cost categories are highest or fastest-growing?
How do we compare to competitors on cost structure?
Are there obvious inefficiencies or redundancies?
What are constraints (quality, service levels, labor relations)?
common_pitfalls: Cutting costs that hurt customer experience
Not distinguishing one-time vs recurring savings
cost_reduction.example_prompt: A manufacturing company needs to cut costs by 20% to remain competitive. Where should they focus?

operations.name: Operational Improvement
operations.description: How can operations be improved for efficiency?
operations.when_used: When operational metrics (throughput, quality, cycle time) lag benchmarks or when scaling

steps: Current state: map process, measure KPIs (throughput, quality, utilization, cycle time)
Benchmarking: best-in-class performance internally and externally
Root cause analysis: why are we underperforming (capacity, quality, process design, people, technology)?
Improvement levers: process redesign, lean/six sigma, automation, training, quality systems, capacity balancing
Quantify impact: efficiency gains, cost reduction, revenue upside from better service
Pilot and scale: test in one location/line, then roll out
Change management and sustainability

clarifying_questions: What are the key operational KPIs?
Where are the bottlenecks in the process?
What does best-in-class look like?
Have we tried improvements before?
common_pitfalls: Optimizing one step without seeing whole system
Not validating root causes with data
operations.example_prompt: A distribution center has 60% utilization vs 85% industry benchmark. How do we improve?

turnaround.name: Turnaround / Restructuring
turnaround.description: How to save a company in crisis?
turnaround.when_used: When a company is losing money, burning cash, facing bankruptcy, or under severe distress

steps: Diagnose crisis: cash runway, profitability by segment, debt obligations, operational issues, root causes
Stabilize immediately: cut unprofitable lines, reduce cash burn, renegotiate debt, secure bridge financing
Assess viability: is core business worth saving? Which assets/segments to keep vs divest?
Strategic options: restructure operations, sell non-core assets, merge/acquire, liquidate
Fix operations: profitability improvements (pricing, costs), efficiency gains
Long-term strategy: sustainable business model, competitive positioning
Stakeholder management: creditors, employees, customers, board

clarifying_questions: How much cash runway do we have?
What is driving the crisis (market, competition, operations)?
Which parts of the business are viable?
What are stakeholder constraints (debt covenants, labor)?
common_pitfalls: Not acting fast enough on cash stabilization
turnaround.example_prompt: A retail chain has lost money for 3 consecutive years, cash runway of 6 months. What should they do?

combo_cases.name: Profitability + Market Entry
combo_cases.description: Company is profitable in home market but considering expansion; need to assess new market while maintaining current profitability
combo_cases.example: Profitable US retailer considering Europe; analyze home profit drivers and new market opportunity

combo_cases.name: M&A + Market Sizing
combo_cases.description: Evaluating acquisition target; need to size target's market to assess growth potential and valuation
combo_cases.example: Tech company acquiring a startup; size the addressable market for the startup's product

combo_cases.name: Turnaround + Profitability
combo_cases.description: Company in distress; diagnose profit issues and develop stabilization plan
combo_cases.example: Retail chain losing money; identify unprofitable stores and product lines to cut

combo_cases.name: Growth + Pricing
combo_cases.description: Company wants to grow revenue; need to evaluate if pricing changes (increases or new tiers) can drive growth
combo_cases.example: SaaS company with flat growth; assess if premium tier or price increase can boost revenue

combo_cases.name: New Product + Market Sizing
combo_cases.description: Evaluate launching new product; need to size the market opportunity first
combo_cases.example: Food company considering plant-based line; size the market before product decision

combo_cases.name: Cost Reduction + Operations
combo_cases.description: Reduce costs through operational improvements rather than just headcount cuts
combo_cases.example: Manufacturer with high costs; improve production efficiency and reduce waste
